Author: mdakin
Content: I try to get .com, .org and .net and not worry about the other TLDs.

Author: KB
Content: I would suggest that any rss feed aggregated through http://web20.originalsignal.com/ should all be on your radar.

Author: orlick
Content: Have a co-founder who is as passionate about communicating ideas to people as you are about hacking code.

Author: brianmckenzie
Content: Absolutely. If you're going to build a company on your .com domain, you want to grab it with every available TLD, and get common mis-spellings as well. It will cost a few hundred bucks, but it's worth it for peace of mind, and it's the best way to defeat squatters.

Author: brianmckenzie
Content: Not to split hairs here, but I don't think networking to that level is at all futile. Your competitors are doing it, and you want every advantage you can get.

Title: What are the best blogs/sites to generate big buzz?

Author: chokosabe
Content: I think its a cool idea. A long time in coming but just at right time. If nothing, the site name is prime real estate.

Author: webwright
Content:
I don't buy this. I've gotten on TechCrunch twice (with related splash on Digg and Del.icio.us), most recently a month ago with http://www.rescuetime.com - which was (at the time) just a series of screenshots and a beta sign up form (i.e. pure vaporware, just about). Neither time did I solicit coverage.

The first time I got on TechCrunch, I was living in Anchorage, Alaska.

The trick is:

1) Build something that is unique (or at least has a twist). No one wants to talk about yet another restaurant review site.

2) Build something controversial (or at least something that is interesting to talk about). I met a guy in Seattle who is trying to build (I kid you not) a social network for car insurance customers...zzzzzzzzzz

3) Talk about what you've built in a clear, compelling, and sticky manner. Try to understand the audience that you're speaking to and communicate it in a way that speaks to THEM. Most hackers suck at this. It requires a combination of information design and copy-writing.

Author: rjb
Content:
Many little sneezes could turn into buzz.

You could let people know about your product/service here. The community here is quite helpful and honest.\nhttp://news.ycombinator.com/comments?id=20342
